I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  Micro, small, and medium-sized enterprises (MSMEs) in India play a crucial role in 
providing employment and help develop rural and low-income areas, thereby reducing regional 
imbalances  and  providing more  equitable  distribution  of  national  income  and  wealth.1 The 
Government of India recognizes MSMEs’ pivotal role in the country’s economic growth and social 
development, and aims to help MSMEs access finance, a key enabler of growth. 
 
2.  RBL Bank is one of the smallest commercial banks in India, but it is also one of the fastest-
growing private banks in the country. It has as its core strategy a focus on inclusive finance 
through support of MSMEs, agriculture, and other development banking activities. The bank is 
expanding its presence across India through a growing network of branches and ATMs, and 
upgrading its traditional delivery channels with modern technology-enabled channels to service 
over 1.3 million customers. In 2016, the Asian Development Bank (ADB) disbursed a loan of $100 
million to RBL for MSME onlending and in 2015 made an equity investment of $44 million for a 
4.6% shareholding stake in RBL to support the bank’s capital base.2 The proposed technical 
assistance (TA) will complement this funding to maximize benefits to MSME borrowers and 
expand financial inclusion. 
  
3.  The TA is expected to assist RBL in (i) improving RBL’s loan origination system (LOS) 
and loan management system (LMS); (ii) rolling out a one-stop rural portal; and (iii) training RBL 
staff on the LOS, the use of handheld devices, and effective customer service. This TA will help 
RBL to continue to grow and reach underserved customers in India, and is an opportunity for ADB 
to further  support the government’s  priority  sector  lending  initiatives and  promote financial 
services in rural India.3 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
4.  India’s financial sector remains largely underdeveloped and is dominated by banks. There 
were 148 commercial banks at the end of FY2015, including 56 regional rural banks. The 
government has prioritized financial inclusion as a key component of its strategy for inclusive 
growth  and  introduced  Pradhan  Mantri  Jan  Dhan  Yojana  (Prime  Minister’s  People  Money 
Scheme), which has resulted in 275.4 million bank accounts opened as of 8 February 2017.4 
Despite the size of the financial sector and the government’s efforts, borrowers have limited 
access to credit and only 6% of them access credit through formal channels.5 To expand access 
to finance, financial institutions need a broader reach to serve underbanked customers in a cost-
efficient manner. 
 
5.  The lack of adequate access to finance has been the biggest challenge to further the 
growth of MSMEs. Financing needs depend on the sector, the size of operations, and the stage

2 
 
of development. Financial institutions typically have limited exposure to MSMEs versus larger, 
more established commercial enterprises due to a higher risk perception and limited access to 
immovable collateral. As of 2012, 29.8 million MSMEs were in operation across all sectors in India, 
employing more than 69 million people.6 These included 2.2 million women-led enterprises, 
demonstrating strong gender importance, and 15.4 million rural enterprises, many of which 
focused on primary agriculture activities. MSMEs accounted for 45% of India’s industrial output 
and 40% of exports. About 94% were unregistered, making statistical estimates difficult; however, 
MSMEs’ contribution to the gross domestic product was estimated to be growing at 11.5% a year 
during 2015, higher than the overall gross domestic product growth (footnote 6). 
 
6.  RBL is expanding its presence across India through a growing network of branches and 
ATMs, and upgrading its traditional delivery channels with modern technology-enabled channels 
such  as  phone  banking,  internet  banking,  and  mobile  banking  to  service  over  1.3  million 
customers. In its commitment to further promote the bank’s agriculture banking and development 
banking and financial inclusion (DBFI)7 segments to capture a larger MSME market, RBL is in the 
process of improving its services with upgraded banking technology. 
 
III.  THE CAPACITY DEVELOPMENT TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
7.  RBL  has  identified  several  areas  outlined  in  paras.  8–16  for  product  and  process 
innovation to (i) improve scale and client outreach, and (ii) reduce costs by enhancing its ability 
to reach and service agriculture banking and DBFI customers. RBL needs to make additional 
investments in its information technology (IT) infrastructure that will allow it to offer its agriculture 
banking and DBFI products to its low-income and rural customers. These investments will allow 
quick turnaround as well as straight-through processing of credit applications, thus improving 
efficiency and reducing potential errors. 
 
8.  Development  banking  and  financial  inclusion  system  enhancements.  RBL  is 
currently serving its DBFI customers through a back-end application implemented during FY2013. 
RBL currently has 1.2 million DBFI customers and plans to increase the customer base by 10% 
annually during 2017 – 2022. After regulatory changes by the Reserve Bank of India, RBL has 
seen major growth in this area and sees a need to enhance its service delivery process. This 
requires an additional investment in IT infrastructure and application development to provide 
tablets with sourcing and collection applications to RBL loan officers. Tablets will offer streamlined 
processing of loan and savings account applications and reduce processing time from 21 days to 
7 days while also enhancing efficiency and accuracy. 
 
9.  Improving the service delivery process entails (i) mapping the process and discussing and 
analyzing requirements, (ii) procuring tablets, (iii) developing and testing the applications, (iv) 
implementing  and  pilot  testing,  (v)  assessing  the  outcome  of  the  pilot  test  and  making 
modifications as needed, and (vi) training the user group and rolling out the final product. 
 
                                                
6  International Finance Corporation. 2012. Micro, Small and Medium Enterprise Finance in India: A Research Study 
on  Needs,  Gaps  and  Way  Forward  (November,  2012).  New  Delhi. 
http://www.ifc.org/wps/wcm/connect/4760ee004ec65f44a165bd45b400a808/MSME+Report-03-01-
2013.pdf?MOD=AJPERES.  
7  Under its Development Banking and Financial Inclusion Group, RBL provides products and services to all the 
constituents of low-income salaried and self-employed individuals in rural and urban areas, and microenterprises 
engaged in services and manufacturing sectors. The group is further subdivided into the following subgroups based 
on client segmentation: affordable financial institutions, microfinance, and microenterprise finance.

3 
 
10.  Rural service portal rollout. RBL will create a one-stop portal where DBFI customers 
can access services, including government schemes such as the Prime Minister’s Umbrella 
Scheme,8 life insurance schemes, and accident insurance schemes; the government’s pension 
scheme; and the Direct Benefit Transfer program, where government subsidies and benefits are 
transmitted directly to beneficiaries’ bank accounts. Other services include enrollment in and 
transfers from government schemes, a digital wallet, remittance services, microinsurance, and 
micro mutual funds. The portal is envisioned to significantly expand service delivery to rural areas 
over time. Currently, rural customers are often unaware of these services and need to visit several 
different branches to access them, limiting penetration in rural areas. The portal would allow 
customers to visit branches in rural areas where a trained RBL staff member could inform them 
about which services are available, and assist them in accessing these services through the portal. 
 
11.  Establishing the portal requires the following steps to be carried out by consultants: 
(i)  identify the services that will be provided through this service portal, including 
enrollment  in  government  schemes,  e.g.,  monetary  transfers,  Aadhaar9 data 
update services, domestic remittance services, microinsurance, and micro mutual 
funds; 
(ii)  identify and finalize a vendor; 
(iii)  discuss and analyze requirements; 
(iv)  develop and test the service portal; 
(v)  implement and pilot test the service portal; 
(vi)  assess the outcome of the pilot test and make modifications as needed; 
(vii)  train the user group on the use of the service portal; and 
(viii)  roll out the successfully tested service portal. 
 
12.  Loan origination and management systems improvement. RBL is working toward 
revamping its core financial inclusion application platform, which will improve its application 
process, risk assessment, decision-making, and monitoring system. The application platform will 
be scalable and will lead to a more automated service delivery process. The new system will also 
allow RBL to roll out products faster, as it would not require manual intervention. The upgraded 
version is also envisioned to be a database for applications rejected after risk assessment. It will 
reduce overall costs for servicing a client, which is a key issue for the distribution of banking 
products in rural India. The new version will 
(i)  implement  a  risk  management  tool  that  will  help  underwriters  automatically 
evaluate a loan application; give alerts on doubtful applications; and evaluate the 
applicants in terms of liquidity, collateral, and credit history; 
(ii)  enable digital storage of documents and transmission of documents to ensure the 
availability of documents throughout the loan life cycle; and 
(iii)  automate the work flow, which will lead to more efficient and faster processing of 
loan applications. 
 
13.  To improve the LOS and LMS, consultants need to (i) identify and finalize a vendor, (ii) 
discuss and analyze requirements, (iii) design and develop the systems, (iv) test and implement 
the systems, (v) train and deliver the systems to the user group, and (vi) roll out the successfully 
tested systems. 
 
                                                
8  The Prime Minister’s Umbrella Scheme aims to provide all people with a savings account. 
9  Aadhaar refers to the unique identification numbers that the Unique Identification Authority of India issues to all 
residents of India.

4 
 
14.  Rollout of tablets for agribusiness loans. Processing agribusiness loans can be time-
intensive and costly. RBL will be improving the sourcing of agribusiness loans by switching the 
process entirely to tablet-based sourcing and processing. Loan officers will be able to visit 
agribusiness clients in the field with tablets, which will reduce the risk of errors and increase the 
speed of processing. As part of this initiative, RBL’s loan sourcing application deployed in the 
fourth quarter of FY2016 has an option to provide applications through tablets, which RBL will use 
going forward. It currently takes 15 days on average to process an agribusiness loan. With the 
tablets, the processing time is expected to be reduced to 7 days. 
 
15.  Switching to tablet-based sourcing and processing entails (i) procuring tablets, (ii) RBL’s 
IT department installing relevant applications, (iii) pilot testing, (iv) assessing the outcome of the 
pilot test and making modifications as needed, and (v) rolling out the successfully tested tablets. 
 
16.  RBL Bank staff training. RBL will train its staff on the use of the new LOS and LMS, the 
rural service portal, and the enhanced DBFI system to facilitate successful implementation. 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
17.  The impact will be increased lending by commercial banks to MSMEs, the agriculture 
sector, and low-income segments with the support of technology. The outcome will be improved 
quality of services provided to agriculture banking and DBFI clients resulting from RBL’s improved 
IT systems. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
18.  The TA will fund the following outputs: (i) the enhancement of RBL’s DBFI system, (ii) the 
implementation and rollout of a rural service portal, (iii) the improvement of RBL’s LOS and LMS, 
(iv) the purchase and rollout of tablets for processing agribusiness loans, and (v) the training of 
staff in the use of these technology solutions. 
 
19.  The TA will build RBL’s capacity by enhancing its LOS and LMS, improving the efficiency 
of loan application processing, and offering additional products and services to its customers. For 
remote customers in rural areas that find it difficult to access services at branches, RBL will 
improve  service  outreach  through  mobile  delivery  channels,  including  branchless  services 
through electronic banking and physical delivery through mobile staff and/or agents with the help 
of tablets. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
20.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,400,000, of which $800,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources). 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
21.  RBL is the beneficiary of the TA and will engage the consulting firms. TA administration 
will also be delegated to RBL, following ADB policies and procedures. RBL’s IT department will 
manage  the  TA  and  has  adequate  management  capabilities  and  processes  in  place  to 
successfully execute the TA. ADB has carried out a procurement capacity assessment of RBL 
which found RBL’s procurement procedures to be satisfactory. RBL’s financial control department 
will  control  the  application  of  procurement  procedures  and  use  of  funds  following  the  TA

5 
 
agreement. RBL’s procurement unit will procure goods and services. RBL will report audit findings 
to ADB on a semiannual basis. 
 
22.  ADB will disburse the TA funds directly to RBL, following ADB’s Technical Assistance 
Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). TA implementation is expected 
to begin in March 2017 and be completed by 31 October 2020. 
 
23.  The execution of the TA requires the selection of consultants for software development to 
develop an IT system based on the inputs from RBL’s agriculture banking team. In order for RBL 
to manage and own the execution of the services, and to respond in a timely manner to local 
needs identified during implementation, it is necessary that TA administration (selection and 
execution) be delegated to RBL. ADB will monitor the individual selection and procurement steps, 
check that the use of funds comply with relevant ADB policies, and check that outputs for 
development effectiveness are on track. 
 
24.  RBL and ADB will enter into a TA agreement that sets out the terms and conditions for the 
TA, including RBL’s responsibilities in selecting, contracting, and managing the outputs; and 
auditing expenditures in a manner acceptable to ADB. The TA agreement will (i) refer to relevant 
agreed selection and contracting frameworks to be used, (ii) confirm ADB’s concurrence at each 
relevant stage of the procurement process, and (iii) require documentation of the execution of the 
TA following ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2013, as amended from time to time) 
and Procurement Guidelines (2015, as amended from time to time) related to the ADB-funded 
procurement of tablets and software development. 
 
25.  RBL will provide ADB with semiannual TA progress reports, including information on the 
(i)  identification of solutions and consultation with ADB; 
(ii)  preparation of product and process-focused implementation plans, including the 
development, testing, and rollout of new products and services such as digital 
banking solutions, a risk management system, and staff training; and 
(iii)  execution, performance tracking, and monitoring of the implementation plans.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
 
26.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $800,000 on a grant basis to 
RBL Bank for Capacity Building for RBL Bank, and hereby reports this action to the Board.
